description: This course will cover everything you need to create a presentation in PowerPoint. These episodes start at the very beginning by exploring the PowerPoint environment, how to add slides to a presentation, insert text and images into slides, create tables and charts, apply design themes, enhance with animation, and prepare to deliver your final presentation.
descriptionMD: This course will cover everything you need to create a presentation in PowerPoint. These episodes start at the very beginning by exploring the PowerPoint environment, how to add slides to a presentation, insert text and images into slides, create tables and charts, apply design themes, enhance with animation, and prepare to deliver your final presentation.
name: PowerPoint 2016 for Mac
subtitle: Presentation application to create slide shows

episodes.description: This course will cover everything you need to create a presentation in PowerPoint. These episodes start at the very beginning by exploring the PowerPoint environment, how to add slides to a presentation, insert text and images into slides, create tables and charts, apply design themes, enhance with animation, and prepare to deliver your final presentation.
episodes.title: Overview

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne kick off their series on PowerPoint for Mac. They begin by familiarizing you with PowerPoint through a short history lesson, pricing tiers, PowerPoint 2016 vs. Office365, and a basic command set.
episodes.title: Introduction to PowerPoint
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.230
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.230 --> 00:00:02.236
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.236 --> 00:00:05.060
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:05.060 --> 00:00:08.025
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.025 --> 00:00:12.226
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.226 --> 00:00:14.334
>> All right, greetings, everyone, and

7
00:00:14.334 --> 00:00:16.780
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:16.780 --> 00:00:18.000
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and

9
00:00:18.000 --> 00:00:23.190
in today's episode we are beginning
our series on PowerPoint 2016 for Mac.

10
00:00:24.270 --> 00:00:26.430
That's right,
the new hotness from Microsoft.

11
00:00:26.430 --> 00:00:29.890
And joining me in the studio to lend
her expertise on that very topic,

12
00:00:29.890 --> 00:00:31.750
our good friend, Miss Vonne Smith.

13
00:00:31.750 --> 00:00:32.358
Vonne, how's it going today?

14
00:00:32.358 --> 00:00:37.200
>> Good, I'm glad to be here for
another exciting round of PowerPoint.

15
00:00:37.200 --> 00:00:39.760
We're gonna be doing it
through the Mac this time.

16
00:00:39.760 --> 00:00:43.980
So I do have a whole series
on PowerPoint for Windows.

17
00:00:43.980 --> 00:00:46.524
And so we wanted to make an entire
thing for Mac, because well,

18
00:00:46.524 --> 00:00:49.070
you could probably say,
it's just pretty much the same.

19
00:00:49.070 --> 00:00:53.705
If you do PowerPoint on PC,
it's the same on a Mac, it's not.

20
00:00:53.705 --> 00:00:55.605
There are significant differences.

21
00:00:55.605 --> 00:00:59.595
And it's kind of like, if it's not in
your environment the way that you're used

22
00:00:59.595 --> 00:01:03.672
to looking at, sometimes I think it can
be, it's kinda hard to kinda translate.

23
00:01:03.672 --> 00:01:05.802
So we figure,
let's not do any translation.

24
00:01:05.802 --> 00:01:07.442
Let's just give it to you in Mac.

25
00:01:07.442 --> 00:01:08.452
>> And that makes total sense.

26
00:01:08.452 --> 00:01:11.224
Let's make the exact same
product completely different.

27
00:01:11.224 --> 00:01:12.390
>> [LAUGH]
>> Hey, it works out for

28
00:01:12.390 --> 00:01:15.992
us because we get to do twice the content
for you good folks out there.

29
00:01:15.992 --> 00:01:18.962
So if you're a Mac enthusiast or
if you're a Windows enthusiast,

30
00:01:18.962 --> 00:01:20.828
we like to cover all of the bases, right?

31
00:01:20.828 --> 00:01:21.360
Not leave anybody out.

32
00:01:21.360 --> 00:01:23.195
We're very inclusive here.

33
00:01:23.195 --> 00:01:26.560
So Vonne, that being said,
where do we begin?

34
00:01:26.560 --> 00:01:29.980
>> So I actually have a PowerPoint
presentation on PowerPoint.

35
00:01:29.980 --> 00:01:31.840
Isn't that a lovely thing there?

36
00:01:31.840 --> 00:01:32.770
>> Very interesting.

37
00:01:32.770 --> 00:01:35.332
I'm pretty sure that's one of those
things that causes the universe to

38
00:01:35.332 --> 00:01:36.067
implode on itself.

39
00:01:36.067 --> 00:01:38.342
>> Yes,
it kind of like we don't understand.

40
00:01:38.342 --> 00:01:40.780
>> No, we actually fire up PowerPoint and
talk about PowerPoint.

41
00:01:40.780 --> 00:01:41.880
It's the end of all human life.

42
00:01:41.880 --> 00:01:43.270
>> It's a meeting to have a meeting.

43
00:01:43.270 --> 00:01:44.130
>> Yeah.

44
00:01:44.130 --> 00:01:45.420
>> Yes, yes, we all know about that.

45
00:01:45.420 --> 00:01:49.110
And speaking of meetings, you might have
been in an office meeting where somebody

46
00:01:49.110 --> 00:01:52.750
is giving a PowerPoint presentation
in that meeting and so

47
00:01:52.750 --> 00:01:54.990
that's exactly what PowerPoint is.

48
00:01:54.990 --> 00:01:59.060
If we come down into this file, you can
see that PowerPoint is a presentation

49
00:01:59.060 --> 00:02:04.550
application within the Office Suite
of applications or programs or

50
00:02:04.550 --> 00:02:10.810
software, whichever word you really wanna
use when talking about these programs.

51
00:02:10.810 --> 00:02:12.665
I'm using the word to
explain the word again.

52
00:02:12.665 --> 00:02:14.880
[LAUGH]
>> No real way around that, is there?

53
00:02:14.880 --> 00:02:17.990
It's like, it's a program,
it's an application.

54
00:02:17.990 --> 00:02:19.340
Six to one,
half a dozen of the other, right?

55
00:02:19.340 --> 00:02:20.405
>> Exactly, yes.

56
00:02:20.405 --> 00:02:23.045
And so this product does presentations.

57
00:02:23.045 --> 00:02:28.035
Word would be your word processing, Excel
would be your spreadsheet application,

58
00:02:28.035 --> 00:02:31.205
Outlook would be your your email software.

59
00:02:31.205 --> 00:02:33.395
So this one works with presentations.

60
00:02:33.395 --> 00:02:36.305
And a presentation is composed of slides,
and

61
00:02:36.305 --> 00:02:40.210
when you give a slideshow,
it is a slideshow.

62
00:02:40.210 --> 00:02:42.955
Wow, we're just circling around,
aren't we?

63
00:02:42.955 --> 00:02:44.924
[LAUGH]
>> Don't think this is from here,

64
00:02:44.924 --> 00:02:45.978
ladies and gentlemen.

65
00:02:45.978 --> 00:02:47.630
>> Yes.
>> Enjoy.

66
00:02:47.630 --> 00:02:51.180
>> You're going to be presenting
your slides in a slideshow.

67
00:02:51.180 --> 00:02:54.020
And those do kind of correlate with
the different things in the environment,

68
00:02:54.020 --> 00:02:57.430
which we will be going over when we
talk about our ribbon and our menus.

69
00:02:57.430 --> 00:02:59.200
You can probably already
start seeing them around.

70
00:02:59.200 --> 00:03:02.320
As you can see,
there are slideshows and slideshows.

71
00:03:02.320 --> 00:03:05.728
>> There's interesting buttons and
icons all around this thing.

72
00:03:05.728 --> 00:03:08.540
So I assume we'll eventually get
into that and see what they do.

73
00:03:08.540 --> 00:03:09.200
>> We will, we will.

74
00:03:09.200 --> 00:03:12.160
Right now we're kind of starting
out with the basic, basic,

75
00:03:12.160 --> 00:03:13.932
let's just start from the very,
very beginning.

76
00:03:13.932 --> 00:03:17.260
>> So I'm a person,
I've never seen PowerPoint before.

77
00:03:17.260 --> 00:03:19.050
I know that it does presentations.

78
00:03:19.050 --> 00:03:21.710
It's a presentation software
suite of some sort.

79
00:03:21.710 --> 00:03:23.810
Now I need to be able to
create presentations.

80
00:03:23.810 --> 00:03:27.240
So I assume that's where
we're gonna begin.

81
00:03:27.240 --> 00:03:28.900
I've installed PowerPoint.

82
00:03:28.900 --> 00:03:30.210
I've launched it.

83
00:03:30.210 --> 00:03:31.397
I wanna make my first slide.

84
00:03:31.397 --> 00:03:34.430
I guess that's a good spot to jump in.

85
00:03:34.430 --> 00:03:35.960
>> Yes, but
that'll be be next episode actually.

86
00:03:35.960 --> 00:03:36.730
>> Really?
>> Yes, yes.

87
00:03:36.730 --> 00:03:37.820
>> We have even more to learn.

88
00:03:37.820 --> 00:03:39.275
We need back story, ladies and gentlemen.

89
00:03:39.275 --> 00:03:41.598
>> [LAUGH]
>> We're gonna talk about Bill Gates and

90
00:03:41.598 --> 00:03:43.168
his life growing up as a child.

91
00:03:43.168 --> 00:03:46.540
[LAUGH]
>> I like to start from, I assume nothing.

92
00:03:46.540 --> 00:03:48.950
I assume you've never even looked at this,

93
00:03:48.950 --> 00:03:52.240
you didn't even know it was a presentation
product until I just told you.

94
00:03:52.240 --> 00:03:53.070
>> That's right.

95
00:03:53.070 --> 00:03:55.810
>> So we're starting even
further back from there,

96
00:03:55.810 --> 00:03:59.174
but I like where you're going and
I will get you there, I promise.

97
00:03:59.174 --> 00:03:59.859
>> I can't wait.
>> [LAUGH]

98
00:03:59.859 --> 00:04:00.359
>> [LAUGH]

99
00:04:00.359 --> 00:04:02.330
>> But talking about PowerPoint as part of

100
00:04:02.330 --> 00:04:06.108
the Office Suite of applications,
I went ahead and put this slide in here.

101
00:04:06.108 --> 00:04:07.840
That just gave you kind of an overview.

102
00:04:07.840 --> 00:04:09.050
There might be some products in

103
00:04:09.050 --> 00:04:10.450
there that you've never even seen before,

104
00:04:10.450 --> 00:04:15.410
maybe Vizio or Infopath or Project.
Some of those,

105
00:04:15.410 --> 00:04:18.520
maybe I would say, lesser known of
the applications within the Office Suite.

106
00:04:18.520 --> 00:04:22.618
But they are part of it, and there's
some over here on the side that I went

107
00:04:22.618 --> 00:04:25.740
ahead and included,
Sway teams and SharePoint.

108
00:04:25.740 --> 00:04:30.200
It really all depends on
what product plan you have.

109
00:04:30.200 --> 00:04:34.170
What access do you have,
whether you've purchased it individually

110
00:04:34.170 --> 00:04:37.970
as your own consumer, or
if you're part of organization?

111
00:04:37.970 --> 00:04:43.320
What version of Office 365 your
organization has purchased for

112
00:04:43.320 --> 00:04:44.737
you, so it really doesn't-
>> You mean this costs me money?

113
00:04:44.737 --> 00:04:46.898
>> [LAUGH]
>> I gotta pay for this?

114
00:04:46.898 --> 00:04:49.210
>> Well, actually no,
there is a free version.

115
00:04:49.210 --> 00:04:50.210
>> But wait, there's more?

116
00:04:50.210 --> 00:04:51.030
>> Exactly.

117
00:04:51.030 --> 00:04:53.158
>> If you act now-
>> So I went ahead and

118
00:04:53.158 --> 00:04:57.048
put this slide in here, and
there's a link down here at the bottom,

119
00:04:57.048 --> 00:04:59.520
that you can visit the Microsoft website.

120
00:04:59.520 --> 00:05:03.260
That will go ahead and give you
an overview of Microsoft for Mac and

121
00:05:03.260 --> 00:05:05.700
what is available to you.

122
00:05:05.700 --> 00:05:07.380
And so definitely check that out.

123
00:05:07.380 --> 00:05:12.102
Because you do have to consider, well, am
I purchasing this as a stand-alone install

124
00:05:12.102 --> 00:05:14.511
or am I purchasing this as an Office 365?

125
00:05:14.511 --> 00:05:19.088
Because that's the whole thing that
we're going with in this slide,

126
00:05:19.088 --> 00:05:22.968
is that when you purchase
a subscription to Office 365,

127
00:05:22.968 --> 00:05:28.260
you are getting a subscription that you
are able to access any of these products.

128
00:05:28.260 --> 00:05:32.010
And be able to download it on
different versions of your machine.

129
00:05:32.010 --> 00:05:37.449
Now as that Office 365 subscriber,
I can then install

130
00:05:37.449 --> 00:05:42.562
PowerPoint, or Word or
Excel locally to my machine.

131
00:05:42.562 --> 00:05:47.060
And then it becomes PowerPoint 2016,
which is kinda weird.

132
00:05:47.060 --> 00:05:48.220
Well, wait, which one am I?

133
00:05:48.220 --> 00:05:49.111
I thought I had Office 365.

134
00:05:49.111 --> 00:05:50.440
Well, you do.

135
00:05:50.440 --> 00:05:51.819
But you also have PowerPoint 2016.

136
00:05:51.819 --> 00:05:56.218
Because back on those product
plans on how you can purchase it,

137
00:05:56.218 --> 00:06:00.617
you could purchase it as a single
standalone install that has no

138
00:06:00.617 --> 00:06:05.040
connection to Office 365 as
a subscription-based model.

139
00:06:05.040 --> 00:06:08.130
The whole idea about having it
as a subscription-based model

140
00:06:08.130 --> 00:06:10.470
is that you get those updates.

141
00:06:10.470 --> 00:06:14.896
If they went ahead and created something
fancy with maybe inserting pictures,

142
00:06:14.896 --> 00:06:16.558
I'm totally making this up.

143
00:06:16.558 --> 00:06:19.624
I don't think they have anything to do
with that, [LAUGH] but they went ahead and

144
00:06:19.624 --> 00:06:20.560
added a small feature.

145
00:06:20.560 --> 00:06:22.600
They go ahead and implement that, and

146
00:06:22.600 --> 00:06:26.810
then as a subscriber you get
those small incremental updates.

147
00:06:26.810 --> 00:06:31.537
As opposed to back in the day, you had
different versions of PowerPoint or

148
00:06:31.537 --> 00:06:36.189
Office, and you would have to wait
years before the next installation of

149
00:06:36.189 --> 00:06:38.262
the new version of the product.

150
00:06:38.262 --> 00:06:42.720
But you can still buy Office that way.

151
00:06:42.720 --> 00:06:45.380
You can buy Office 2016, get a disk.

152
00:06:45.380 --> 00:06:46.826
I don't know if they make
it on a disk anymore.

153
00:06:46.826 --> 00:06:47.623
[LAUGH] Right?

154
00:06:47.623 --> 00:06:48.675
>> Yeah, you probably download it.

155
00:06:48.675 --> 00:06:51.768
>> Exactly, but back in the day,
you get a CD and you install it, and

156
00:06:51.768 --> 00:06:52.900
everything like that.

157
00:06:52.900 --> 00:06:57.403
So I just wanted to kinda clarify here
that I do have an Office 365 account,

158
00:06:57.403 --> 00:07:00.938
but I'm using this as a locally
installed version of it, and

159
00:07:00.938 --> 00:07:02.976
it becomes PowerPoint 2016.

160
00:07:02.976 --> 00:07:07.490
But back to what you were saying,
Daniel, well, do I have to pay for this?

161
00:07:07.490 --> 00:07:08.528
You don't, actually.

162
00:07:08.528 --> 00:07:10.810
If you wanted,
they do have a free version.

163
00:07:10.810 --> 00:07:11.944
>> I thought you were
gonna say torrent sites.

164
00:07:11.944 --> 00:07:13.531
>> [LAUGH]
>> I know Vonne.

165
00:07:13.531 --> 00:07:14.532
Gotta watch her.

166
00:07:14.532 --> 00:07:16.572
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] I know you.

167
00:07:16.572 --> 00:07:18.238
Come on now.

168
00:07:18.238 --> 00:07:20.940
No, we are legit here.

169
00:07:20.940 --> 00:07:25.860
And we're saying that with a Microsoft
account that you can go ahead and

170
00:07:25.860 --> 00:07:30.862
sign up for, you have access to
the online versions of these products and

171
00:07:30.862 --> 00:07:33.230
these different applications.

172
00:07:33.230 --> 00:07:38.200
So there is a PowerPoint Online that
you could use, and that is free.

173
00:07:38.200 --> 00:07:41.730
It is mobile, in the sense that you would
have to access that on your computer

174
00:07:41.730 --> 00:07:44.279
through your browser with
your Internet connection.

175
00:07:44.279 --> 00:07:47.120
And that's how you could access it.

176
00:07:47.120 --> 00:07:49.720
So you can use this in a free model.

177
00:07:49.720 --> 00:07:55.210
>> And would that be as full featured as
that standalone download to your desktop?

178
00:07:55.210 --> 00:07:58.879
>> There's a lot of features that
are the same, but just like with anything,

179
00:07:58.879 --> 00:08:02.490
if this is the purchased version,
I'm gonna have much more capability,

180
00:08:02.490 --> 00:08:04.370
the full capability of the software.

181
00:08:04.370 --> 00:08:09.070
With my 365 or my local installation
of a purchased product.

182
00:08:09.070 --> 00:08:12.900
But a lot of the things that we're going
to be doing you can still go ahead and

183
00:08:12.900 --> 00:08:16.250
do a lot of the basics in
the free online version.

184
00:08:16.250 --> 00:08:19.490
>> So if I just need some make some
quick and easy Powerpoint slides,

185
00:08:19.490 --> 00:08:22.900
maybe do a presentation
at a work function or

186
00:08:22.900 --> 00:08:26.870
maybe some other organization I'm involved
with, I can use that free version.

187
00:08:26.870 --> 00:08:30.040
But if I do presentations
probably as my job,

188
00:08:30.040 --> 00:08:32.220
I'm gonna wanna go with
the more fully functional.

189
00:08:32.220 --> 00:08:33.557
>> Yeah exactly, that's how it goes.

190
00:08:33.557 --> 00:08:37.723
And the nice thing about being in Office
365 user is you could always access those

191
00:08:37.723 --> 00:08:39.220
that online version as well.

192
00:08:39.220 --> 00:08:43.444
So like you're saying if you're on the go,
and you're at the airport or wherever you

193
00:08:43.444 --> 00:08:46.975
could go ahead and still do everything-
>> You know what happens a lot is you show

194
00:08:46.975 --> 00:08:49.138
up somewhere like yeah,
I wanna do a presentation.

195
00:08:49.138 --> 00:08:50.771
And they're like, here's your laptop.

196
00:08:50.771 --> 00:08:53.800
They give you a laptop that they use for
presentations.

197
00:08:53.800 --> 00:08:55.713
Look, it doesn't have what I need on it.

198
00:08:55.713 --> 00:08:56.702
That's awesome.

199
00:08:56.702 --> 00:08:59.242
Now it doesn't matter, you just get
into the Cloud and there it is.

200
00:08:59.242 --> 00:09:00.589
You just launch it from there.

201
00:09:00.589 --> 00:09:02.899
>> Yeah, and
then the whole idea with the One Drive,

202
00:09:02.899 --> 00:09:04.550
One Drive being a service that's.

203
00:09:04.550 --> 00:09:08.510
It's like Dropbox or Google Drive if
you're familiar with any of those terms.

204
00:09:08.510 --> 00:09:12.220
But it's just a storage location for
your files in the cloud for

205
00:09:12.220 --> 00:09:16.100
you to be able to access anywhere
with an internet connection.

206
00:09:16.100 --> 00:09:20.090
So talking about these different
versions of PowerPoint we've been going.

207
00:09:20.090 --> 00:09:22.688
I just wanted to give a history lesson or

208
00:09:22.688 --> 00:09:28.068
just kinda a back story of the different
versions that you have with PowerPoint.

209
00:09:28.068 --> 00:09:31.217
We're going only back to 2003
in the PC version and back-

210
00:09:31.217 --> 00:09:32.310
>> The last time I used PowerPoint.

211
00:09:32.310 --> 00:09:33.774
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Right.

212
00:09:33.774 --> 00:09:37.739
[LAUGH] Back of course when they did the
Mac versions they always were a year off.

213
00:09:37.739 --> 00:09:38.601
So the PC and

214
00:09:38.601 --> 00:09:43.702
Windows versions never really matched
up in the sense of the numbers.

215
00:09:43.702 --> 00:09:46.428
Now the nice thing is that PowerPoint for

216
00:09:46.428 --> 00:09:50.448
Mac really does look almost
identical to PowerPoint in PC.

217
00:09:50.448 --> 00:09:53.304
So the kind of switching
of being bilingual,

218
00:09:53.304 --> 00:09:58.280
before it was a little rough there
switching back and forth between products.

219
00:09:58.280 --> 00:10:04.520
But now, looking at PowerPoint or
Word or Excel on PC and then looking

220
00:10:04.520 --> 00:10:09.183
on it on your Mac, it's more similar than
it's ever been which is really nice.

221
00:10:09.183 --> 00:10:11.505
[LAUGH]
>> And that makes sense because you think

222
00:10:11.505 --> 00:10:14.402
about if you,
going into history lessons, right?

223
00:10:14.402 --> 00:10:19.093
Where Mac was a completely different
architecture than PCs were.

224
00:10:19.093 --> 00:10:22.578
And then all of a sudden one day they said
you know what, we're not going to do that

225
00:10:22.578 --> 00:10:26.078
anymore, got Intel based Macintosh and
you've got Intel based PCs obviously.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore working with Slides in PowerPoint 2016. They start by showing you how to create a new Slide and applying a Layout. Then they look at editing Slides and Layouts; rearranging slide order, duplicating, deleting, hiding slides. Finally, they explain selecting and modifying Slide or Object content.
episodes.title: Slides

Thank you for watching ITProTV

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne begin explaining how to work with text in PowerPoint 2016. They start by showing you how to add text to a placeholder, autosizing text, and Auto-Correct options. They also show adding text to the Speaker Notes and inserting text box into a blank slide.
episodes.title: Work with Text

So we're gonna add text

And I have filled in the content

As a small little side note,

You don't have to keep all

And if I click on that,

And then I can hit the Delete key,

Well-

All right, so now that I've gone and put

93

Now, when I get into some more complex,

98
00:04:17.195 --> 00:04:19.707
And what we can do when it gets too much.

99
00:04:19.707 --> 00:04:23.555
And PowerPoint gives us even

100
00:04:23.555 --> 00:04:28.705
So let's go ahead and click to add a title

101

00:04:48.240 --> 00:04:52.810
If you just start typing, and I'm gonna

00:05:21.440 --> 00:05:25.220
You can't just jump all willy-nilly

00:05:26.030 --> 00:05:28.890
That's we know how to actually have

125

How do I do that?

126

127
00:05:36.830 --> 00:05:37.408
When you Enter,

138
00:06:19.400 --> 00:06:21.500

139

And then because I'm in
this indented list level,

140

when I hit Enter it's gonna key
me in that same list level.

141
00:06:29.110 --> 00:06:30.420
And then I can say sub topic.

142
00:06:31.830 --> 00:06:32.520
If I could type.

143
00:06:34.070 --> 00:06:36.030
Two, 23.
And then if I hit Enter,

144
00:06:36.030 --> 00:06:37.430
what if I want to go in one more time?

145
00:06:37.430 --> 00:06:38.690
You just go ahead and

146

you in then this computer sub sub one.

147
00:06:42.450 --> 00:06:45.800
Now, how many levels do
you want to go down now?

148
00:06:45.800 --> 00:06:49.890
If I'm making a Power Point presentation,
if I have this many levels,

149
00:06:49.890 --> 00:06:52.660

150
00:06:52.660 --> 00:06:57.650

would say kinda the higher levels.

151
00:06:57.650 --> 00:07:00.890
As a suggestion,
maybe only go one level deep.

152

So you're going to have to
kinda judge on your own

156
00:07:12.220 --> 00:07:15.470
Somebody teaching in a high school

157
00:07:15.470 --> 00:07:18.120

to a major corporation.

158
00:07:18.120 --> 00:07:20.930
There's going to be different
types of information.

159
00:07:20.930 --> 00:07:25.670
And if this is the main content

160
00:07:25.670 --> 00:07:27.680

161
00:07:27.680 --> 00:07:29.700
Science lesson,
that's what I'm trying to go with.

162
00:07:29.700 --> 00:07:33.550
Then you might have a lot of text and
a lot of different levels.

163
00:07:33.550 --> 00:07:36.410
I'm gonna go ahead and
undo those last two that I did.

164
00:07:36.410 --> 00:07:40.230
But to say that I am back here on sub one,
well, sub sub 1.

165
00:07:40.230 --> 00:07:41.880
I wanna get back out.

166
00:07:41.880 --> 00:07:44.660
Now, if I hit Enter I'm
still on that same level.

167
00:07:44.660 --> 00:07:48.910
If you can tab to get in,
you can shift tab to get out.

168
00:07:48.910 --> 00:07:52.078
So if I hold my shift key and then click
my tab, you see how I go one level out.

169
00:07:52.078 --> 00:07:53.377
And if I do it again,

170
00:07:53.377 --> 00:07:57.357
shift tab, then it takes me all
the way out to that main level.

171
00:07:57.357 --> 00:08:02.180
So that tab and shift tab is a great
handy way of Entering in text, so

172
00:08:02.180 --> 00:08:06.520
you don't have to go up to the ribbon and
use the buttons.

173
00:08:06.520 --> 00:08:08.840
Now as I say that,
let me show you where those buttons are,

174
00:08:08.840 --> 00:08:11.200
because maybe you don't
want to use the tab key.

175
00:08:11.200 --> 00:08:13.760
I would highly suggest it because
it makes it a lot easier.

176
00:08:13.760 --> 00:08:15.200
And this is not just for PowerPoint.

177
00:08:15.200 --> 00:08:18.834
This is in pretty much anything
within office that you can do, and

178
00:08:18.834 --> 00:08:21.022
I guess I just want to say anything
>> Word.

179
00:08:21.022 --> 00:08:21.683
>> Word.
Yeah,

180
00:08:21.683 --> 00:08:22.324
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

181
00:08:22.324 --> 00:08:23.745
>> I'm like you can't really do it on

182
00:08:23.745 --> 00:08:26.448
Excel, but definitely with Word and
PowerPoint you can do that.

183
00:08:26.448 --> 00:08:30.019
And even with your emails and
things like that.

184
00:08:30.019 --> 00:08:33.227
So, I'm here and let's go ahead and
say a main topic.

185
00:08:33.227 --> 00:08:35.290
I think this is topic three.

186
00:08:35.290 --> 00:08:40.650
If I wanted to enter and then indent,
I have on the home tab of our ribbon,

187
00:08:40.650 --> 00:08:46.170
you do have your indents and your, I call
them out dent, but that's an indent less.

188
00:08:46.170 --> 00:08:51.380
So I can indent and then it's going to go
ahead and move me into that sub-topic.

189
00:08:51.380 --> 00:08:52.880
And then if I click here,

190
00:08:52.880 --> 00:08:56.890
I can click the indent less with
the outdent button as I have named it.

191
00:08:56.890 --> 00:09:01.140
And you can move around from your
different levels of your list in that way.

192
00:09:01.140 --> 00:09:03.230
So we're gonna go ahead and
keep on adding a few more things.

193
00:09:03.230 --> 00:09:06.085
We're gonna type in more and
then some more stuff.

194
00:09:06.085 --> 00:09:09.230
And more,
cuz I can't think of anything else to say.

195
00:09:09.230 --> 00:09:10.600
What should I say, Daniel?

196
00:09:10.600 --> 00:09:13.800
>> You should start quoting Hamlet,
that's always fun.

197
00:09:13.800 --> 00:09:14.910
>> Okay.
Well, help me then.

198
00:09:14.910 --> 00:09:16.792
>> Okay.
To be or not to be, right?

199
00:09:16.792 --> 00:09:17.321
>> There we go.

200
00:09:17.321 --> 00:09:24.287
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] That one, to be or not to be.

201
00:09:24.287 --> 00:09:25.279
>> And then you can break that down.

202
00:09:25.279 --> 00:09:28.152
You got to be and not to be,
they're two sections, right?

203
00:09:28.152 --> 00:09:29.650
And you can spread that out.

204
00:09:29.650 --> 00:09:30.504
>> Yes.
>> It's a lot of fun.

205
00:09:30.504 --> 00:09:31.845
[LAUGH]
>> That is the question.

206
00:09:31.845 --> 00:09:32.453
>> That's right.

207
00:09:32.453 --> 00:09:33.088
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

208
00:09:33.088 --> 00:09:33.588
>> Right?

209
00:09:33.588 --> 00:09:34.787
And so as you can see,

210
00:09:34.787 --> 00:09:35.984
when I keep on going,

211
00:09:35.984 --> 00:09:40.378
I don't know if you've noticed that
the more bullet points that I'm adding,

212
00:09:40.378 --> 00:09:45.070
it's automatically sizing the amount of
information in that place for the text.

213
00:09:45.070 --> 00:09:47.140
It's not making the place a little bigger.

214
00:09:47.140 --> 00:09:48.740
>> It's squishing everything down.

215
00:09:48.740 --> 00:09:51.740
>> It's auto-sizing the text.

216
00:09:51.740 --> 00:09:56.995
If I keep on going,

217
00:09:56.995 --> 00:09:59.910
[LAUGH] Keeps on resizing, resizing.

218
00:09:59.910 --> 00:10:01.490
And more quotes.

219
00:10:02.600 --> 00:10:03.360
>> More quests.

220
00:10:03.360 --> 00:10:04.040
>> More quests?

221
00:10:04.040 --> 00:10:04.630
Yes, there we go.

222
00:10:04.630 --> 00:10:06.580
And it keeps on auto resizing.

223
00:10:06.580 --> 00:10:08.320
Now there's a couple of things
that's gonna happen here.

224
00:10:08.320 --> 00:10:11.400
And it's all about the smart tag.

225

I love the smart tags, because they
can really, really help you out.

226
00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:19.527
This little thing that's kind of, that
popped up over here on the left hand side

the arrows on it, this is our smart tag.

228
00:10:24.111 --> 00:10:29.670
These smart tags are going to pop up
as we enter in any type of information.

229
00:10:29.670 --> 00:10:33.670
Mostly the text, but

Vonne, those are the names that you need

00:22:06.930 --> 00:22:08.580

00:22:08.580 --> 00:22:10.990

it will remember.

00:22:10.990 --> 00:22:13.560
And that way you can
start adding terms that

00:22:13.560 --> 00:22:16.730

00:22:16.730 --> 00:22:22.240
And on that right-clicking, lets just go
ahead and do it here, the right-clicking

00:22:22.240 --> 00:22:28.210

Very lovely.

00:22:28.720 --> 00:22:31.917
>> All right, well thank you so much

How is that I can do that?

>> The nice thing is

478

Now, I'm gonna make this a little bit

00:23:07.690 --> 00:23:10.040

00:23:10.040 --> 00:23:11.940

00:23:12.960 --> 00:23:15.930
icon to be able to make this a little

Bullets button right there, it will add

00:23:53.359 --> 00:23:57.773

So you can add text

00:24:22.090 --> 00:24:23.930
You can add text into the slide.

And the last one that I want to show you

00:24:27.800 --> 00:24:33.230
Maybe you don't have a content

00:24:42.530 --> 00:24:43.590
Cuz maybe I wanna freeform it.

I wanna put like,
maybe one text block over here and

Now notice, it does go ahead,

00:25:17.130 --> 00:25:19.310
But it automatically changed
the size of the box or

00:25:19.310 --> 00:25:23.870
at least the height of the box to

And this is where you would need to hit

00:25:28.890 --> 00:25:30.440
you can do all the different things.

00:25:30.440 --> 00:25:34.987
You can still tab and

Look at how fast I'm typing.

>> Right.

>> It's like 120 words a minute.

00:25:39.639 --> 00:25:41.450

And so you can add your text into your
text box and this becomes an object.

00:25:46.440 --> 00:25:50.350
Just like any other object that we're
going to have in our slides, and

531
00:25:50.350 --> 00:25:51.310
we can move it around.

532
00:25:51.310 --> 00:25:55.347
And you can start formatting it and
select the text like so.

533
00:25:55.347 --> 00:25:56.634
>> Very cool.

534
00:25:56.634 --> 00:26:00.371
>> So we've been adding text into our

00:26:00.371 --> 00:26:03.555

But I have a lot more to show

And we're going to cut, copy, and paste.

But I feel like you're giving

00:26:13.775 --> 00:26:16.744
I think it's time wrap this up,

00:26:16.744 --> 00:26:18.408
[LAUGH] I think you

[LAUGH]

But the good news is,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne continue explaining how to work with text in PowerPoint 2016. They pick back up by looking at Outline view, working with cut, copy, and paste, and performing Find and Replace.
episodes.title: Work with Text Part 2

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.375

3

4
00:00:12.000 --> 00:00:13.832
>> All right, greetings everyone and

00:00:16.588 --> 00:00:20.693
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and in

8
00:00:23.217 --> 00:00:26.260
Actually, continuing a conversation

9

This is our part two of

And joining us back in the studio yet

our good friend, Ms. Vonne Smith.

Vonne, welcome back my friend.

How are you?

14
00:00:36.407 --> 00:00:40.916
I'm ready to continue on with working with
our text because we learned how to type

00:00:42.970 --> 00:00:46.680
But what about if I wanted to take

Maybe you've given me

>> Yes, you gave me text documents that

00:01:06.149 --> 00:01:08.661
Cuz I don't know, maybe you don't

00:01:08.661 --> 00:01:09.404
>> That's right.

27
00:01:09.404 --> 00:01:10.890
You're the Power Point Queen.

28
00:01:10.890 --> 00:01:13.108
I'm over here Power Point destitute.

00:01:13.108 --> 00:01:14.678
I'm like I need your help.

30
00:01:14.678 --> 00:01:17.543
>> Yes,
just give me all the information you want.

31
00:01:17.543 --> 00:01:18.973
I'll put it together and
make it look pretty.

00:01:18.973 --> 00:01:19.870
>> I like it.

33
00:01:19.870 --> 00:01:22.577
>> So yeah.
So but before we can get into getting it

00:01:26.861 --> 00:01:31.392

00:01:31.392 --> 00:01:33.587
You gotta make sure you

So let's jump into a file that I

And it has a few slides, it has a bulleted
list here, it has some paragraphs, and

00:01:47.969 --> 00:01:52.298
it actually has a slide here that is going

41
00:01:52.298 --> 00:01:54.265
How may I get what I want?

42
00:01:54.265 --> 00:01:57.371
The first way is to click,
hold and drag with your mouse.

43
00:01:57.371 --> 00:01:59.957
So I'm gonna actually,
let's close these notes so

00:01:59.957 --> 00:02:01.787
you could see us a little bit better.

45
00:02:01.787 --> 00:02:03.393
Maybe zoom that slide in.

46
00:02:03.393 --> 00:02:05.714
Get just the text are is just
a little too small for me.

47
00:02:05.714 --> 00:02:08.300
If I wanna click hold and
drag you also have to have your I Beam.

48
00:02:08.300 --> 00:02:10.796
So if I take my I Beam and
I click hold and

49
00:02:10.796 --> 00:02:15.242

00:02:15.242 --> 00:02:18.470
maybe I get to right about there and

52

Now, this is something that I
always tell people to watch out for

is make sure that if you didn't get

it's like, I really wanted to go all

55
00:02:30.352 --> 00:02:34.971
A common thing that people do is
they try to extend the selection

56
00:02:34.971 --> 00:02:39.950
technique with your mouse cursor and
then it does this weird thing.

57
00:02:39.950 --> 00:02:42.843
And it does the,
it does it what we call drag and drop.

58
00:02:42.843 --> 00:02:45.769
So people come within
the already selected area.

59
00:02:45.769 --> 00:02:49.540
They start dragging this way and then
they, I don't know what's going on and

60
00:02:49.540 --> 00:02:52.330
they let go and
they're like what just happened?

61
00:02:52.330 --> 00:02:56.810
Very common mistake that people do
because this is, it could be a good and

00:02:56.810 --> 00:02:57.410
a bad thing.

00:02:57.410 --> 00:03:00.040
To me it's a bad thing,
cuz it kinda throws me off.

64

But what Office does is it enables

00:03:04.870 --> 00:03:09.349
If I wanted to move the selected

00:03:11.555 --> 00:03:16.384
The problem is is that it can kinda

00:03:16.384 --> 00:03:18.230

69
00:03:18.230 --> 00:03:19.619
So be careful about that.

70
00:03:20.680 --> 00:03:24.580
My suggestion is, if you get it to

00:03:24.580 --> 00:03:30.010

72

Click off to a blank area,

Come back and go again and get all the

74
00:03:38.334 --> 00:03:41.584

75
00:03:41.584 --> 00:03:43.912
Because if you're over here,
you don't get an I beam.

76
00:03:43.912 --> 00:03:47.416
You have to have an I beam
if you're selecting text.

77
00:03:47.416 --> 00:03:52.880
So really small, but important to make
sure that you know where you're going.

78
00:03:52.880 --> 00:03:55.650
So selecting with your mouse
is one way to do that.

79
00:03:55.650 --> 00:04:00.584
There's some other neat little tricks
that you can do with selecting words and

80

or paragraphs with your mouse.

81
00:04:02.860 --> 00:04:07.504
If you double-click on the word,
word, it will select that word.

82
00:04:07.504 --> 00:04:10.844
Double-click on the word, arrows,
it selects that one word.

83
00:04:10.844 --> 00:04:16.031
If l wanted to select the entire
paragraph, you can triple click 123,

84
00:04:16.031 --> 00:04:20.736
123 and then it will go ahead and
select that entire paragraph.

85
00:04:20.736 --> 00:04:26.517
And essentially well that's not really

86
00:04:26.517 --> 00:04:32.147
because you hit the enter key after this

87
00:04:32.147 --> 00:04:34.812
And so
that's what it's seeing as a paragraph.

88
00:04:34.812 --> 00:04:38.577
If I come over here to slide three,
this is probably what we would think in

89
00:04:38.577 --> 00:04:41.259
the normal terms of,
well, that's a paragraph.

90
00:04:41.259 --> 00:04:43.056
It's many words together.

91
00:04:43.056 --> 00:04:44.030
It does the same thing.

92
00:04:44.030 --> 00:04:48.837
123, it goes ahead and selects that
paragraph and you can kind of,

93
00:04:48.837 --> 00:04:53.656
just like it's a quicker way of doing
things which I always like to do.

94
00:04:53.656 --> 00:04:55.768
Let me go back to slide two cuz there's,

95
00:04:55.768 --> 00:04:59.075
we're talking about all these
different ways with our mouse.

96
00:04:59.075 --> 00:05:03.783
Like we have the mouse, we click hold and
drag and that's great but using your

97
00:05:03.783 --> 00:05:08.590
keyboard can really help and I'm
a keyboard person so I like to use that.

98
00:05:08.590 --> 00:05:13.690
If I have my cursor here but you do have
to kinda start where the flashing cursor

99
00:05:13.690 --> 00:05:17.850
needs to be at, so you do have to use
your mouse in some parts of that.

100
00:05:17.850 --> 00:05:21.851
If I wanted to select this word,
I can hold my Shift key down.

101
00:05:21.851 --> 00:05:25.975
If you hold the Shift key down and then
you use your arrow keys on your keyboard,

102
00:05:25.975 --> 00:05:27.390
I can one, two, three.

103
00:05:27.390 --> 00:05:30.450
I can click with that right
arrow to go ahead and

104
00:05:30.450 --> 00:05:34.120
select those particular characters and
I can click, click, click, click,

105
00:05:34.120 --> 00:05:38.620
click all the way to the end and
then I can select that text.

106
00:05:38.620 --> 00:05:42.760
Back where we are saying like where
I kinda half selected a word.

107
00:05:42.760 --> 00:05:45.547
This is where you can use it together
where I click hold and drag.

108
00:05:45.547 --> 00:05:48.519
Get a selection started,
I just want to get a little bit more.

109
00:05:48.519 --> 00:05:52.351
Hold that Shift key down,
use those arrow keys on your keyboard, and

110
00:05:52.351 --> 00:05:56.910
you can get just those little bits of text
that you might have missed from selecting

111
00:05:56.910 --> 00:05:57.921
with your mouse.

112
00:05:57.921 --> 00:05:59.408
So it's not one or the other.

113
00:05:59.408 --> 00:06:01.830
You can do it all together.

114
00:06:01.830 --> 00:06:06.312
It's all about selecting, so whichever
way is going to be easiest for you,

115
00:06:06.312 --> 00:06:08.100

116
00:06:08.100 --> 00:06:12.350
There are a few other little
shortcuts here that you can do in Mac

117
00:06:12.350 --> 00:06:13.760

118
00:06:13.760 --> 00:06:15.146
I'm holding the Shift key down.

119
00:06:15.146 --> 00:06:17.560
Using the arrow key it's
gonna go by character.

120
00:06:17.560 --> 00:06:19.285
But what if I wanted to go by word?

121
00:06:19.285 --> 00:06:23.754
If you wanted to go by word, you can
hold your ALT key down or option really.

122
00:06:23.754 --> 00:06:28.232
It's Opt or Alt, and I hit the arrow,

00:17:46.273 --> 00:17:50.095
something like that, it is ubiquitous
throughout any kind of text editing.

350
00:17:50.095 --> 00:17:52.298
Do we find that here
in PowerPoint as well?

351
00:17:52.298 --> 00:17:52.845
>> Yes we do.
>> Amen.

352
00:17:52.845 --> 00:17:57.371
>> I have a document, cuz maybe you
went ahead and gave me all this text.

353
00:17:57.371 --> 00:17:58.055
>> I did.

354
00:17:58.055 --> 00:18:00.905
I started making my
presentation about Alice.

355
00:18:00.905 --> 00:18:05.014
And we're talking about some rabbits and
things like that.

356
00:18:05.014 --> 00:18:07.073
But Alice doesn't live here anymore.

357
00:18:07.073 --> 00:18:12.159
Or maybe, and this could be a perfect
example of Alice was the boss and

358
00:18:12.159 --> 00:18:16.910
now the boss's name is Bob, or
Daniel, Daniel is the boss now.

359
00:18:16.910 --> 00:18:18.392
[LAUGH]
>> Promotion.

360
00:18:18.392 --> 00:18:21.302
[LAUGH]
>> But I had this entire presentation that

361
00:18:21.302 --> 00:18:24.570
has the word Alice
throughout the whole thing.

362
00:18:24.570 --> 00:18:30.300
Do I want to go through and change
every single instance of this by hand?

363
00:18:30.300 --> 00:18:35.559
No, I want PowerPoint to find it for
me, and then I can replace it.

364
00:18:35.559 --> 00:18:38.530
So let's jump into how this works.

365
00:18:38.530 --> 00:18:42.680
Up here at the top, towards our title bar,

366
00:18:42.680 --> 00:18:47.060
there's a place where you can Search
in presentation, that's our find.

367
00:18:48.380 --> 00:18:50.990
You do have a little drop down
next to it cuz we are going

368
00:18:50.990 --> 00:18:53.250
to get into that advanced Find and
Replace.

369
00:18:53.250 --> 00:18:56.924
Because the Find in this particular area,
it's only gonna find.

370
00:18:56.924 --> 00:19:00.627
It's not gonna give me any other options
besides just I'm gonna tell you where

371
00:19:00.627 --> 00:19:01.140
it's at.

372
00:19:01.140 --> 00:19:05.540
Which could be nice because maybe
I was trying to find where I,

373
00:19:05.540 --> 00:19:08.700
maybe have 150 slides,
and I need to find where

374
00:19:08.700 --> 00:19:13.050
I mentioned you as the vice president,
and I need to find that.

375
00:19:13.050 --> 00:19:16.850
I don't necessarily need to replace it,
I just need to find where it was, so

376
00:19:16.850 --> 00:19:19.520
then I can make some
different modifications.

377
00:19:19.520 --> 00:19:22.210
So that's where a find
would be appropriate.

378
00:19:22.210 --> 00:19:24.370
So let's go ahead and type in Alice.

379
00:19:24.370 --> 00:19:28.190
And then if I hit Enter,
it's going to say well there it is, and

380
00:19:28.190 --> 00:19:32.430
it highlighted on slide 2
that there is the word Alice.

381
00:19:32.430 --> 00:19:34.990
And then I have my forward and
backward buttons,

382
00:19:34.990 --> 00:19:37.380
well where's the next instance of Alice?

383
00:19:37.380 --> 00:19:39.950
There it is, and we go ahead and
click all the way through.

384
00:19:39.950 --> 00:19:41.130
It found it in the speaker notes.

385
00:19:41.130 --> 00:19:43.889
So that's a nice thing that it's
searching the entire presentation.

386
00:19:43.889 --> 00:19:48.180
It's not just searching your slides,
it will search your speaker notes.

387
00:19:48.180 --> 00:19:50.644
And I can keep on moving through and
it shows me.

388
00:19:50.644 --> 00:19:53.830
I think I've looped a couple of times,
no, there I am.

389
00:19:53.830 --> 00:19:57.430
Now it says I finished searching
the presentation, thank you very much.

390
00:19:57.430 --> 00:19:59.900
And I did exactly what you told me to do.

391
00:19:59.900 --> 00:20:03.960
But this is where what if I wanted
to replace Alice with Daniel.

392
00:20:03.960 --> 00:20:08.610
Drop that down and
I can go into either the Advanced Find or

393
00:20:08.610 --> 00:20:10.750
the Replace, either one is going to work.

394
00:20:10.750 --> 00:20:15.950
Because once I get into Advanced Find
there is a button here for replace,

395
00:20:15.950 --> 00:20:21.762
and once I click Replace, then it gives
me that option of Find what replace with.

396
00:20:21.762 --> 00:20:26.108
And sometimes I usually just jump right
to this dialog box to begin with,

397
00:20:26.108 --> 00:20:29.030
because most of the time I am replacing.

398
00:20:29.030 --> 00:20:29.947
And so I'm gonna-
>> And

399
00:20:29.947 --> 00:20:31.610
obviously you've got
a couple of options there.

400
00:20:31.610 --> 00:20:34.460
One says Replace,
the other says Replace all.

401
00:20:34.460 --> 00:20:38.150
So I assume one does one instance and
the other does all instance.

402
00:20:38.150 --> 00:20:42.970
>> Correct, because maybe there
are places in there where I want to keep

403
00:20:42.970 --> 00:20:47.100
the word Alice because it's
in a different context.

404
00:20:47.100 --> 00:20:52.926
And it's not just saying that Alice as a
president, it's a Alice as just a person.

405
00:20:52.926 --> 00:20:55.788
Or maybe there's a different Alice,
there's Alice Smith and

406
00:20:55.788 --> 00:20:56.873
there's Alice Jones.

407
00:20:56.873 --> 00:21:02.422
And so we need to make sure that I can
go through and find each instance and

408
00:21:02.422 --> 00:21:06.910
then one by one say find,
replace, find, replace.

409
00:21:06.910 --> 00:21:12.030
So Find What, Replace, we've already found
Alice, we wanna replace it with Daniel.

410
00:21:12.030 --> 00:21:16.570
Now, point it out here,
Match case, Find whole words only.

411
00:21:17.890 --> 00:21:20.234
Let's go ahead and just find the next one.

412
00:21:20.234 --> 00:21:27.130
Right there, Alice's, you see how
it's got that possession there.

413
00:21:27.130 --> 00:21:32.691
If I wanted it to replace it,
here that would probably be appropriate,

414
00:21:32.691 --> 00:21:36.505
but what if it was Alice's,
I don't even know.

415
00:21:36.505 --> 00:21:39.244
>> [LAUGH]
>> But there's some other letters

416
00:21:39.244 --> 00:21:42.344
associated with it, or maybe-
>> This is like suffixes and

417
00:21:42.344 --> 00:21:45.680
things that might affect to
a way that you don't want.

418
00:21:45.680 --> 00:21:51.270
>> Or if I was finding Dan and replace
with Bob but there's Daniel, right?

419
00:21:51.270 --> 00:21:52.710
So there's Dan and Daniel.

420
00:21:52.710 --> 00:21:55.724
So it would find just parts of a word.

421
00:21:55.724 --> 00:22:01.471
So telling it to Find whole words only,
is something that you need to figure out,

422
00:22:01.471 --> 00:22:04.890
do you want it to do that or
not, or Match case.

423
00:22:04.890 --> 00:22:09.980
What if I have, it's only gonna find
upper case Alice, if I have Match case.

424
00:22:09.980 --> 00:22:13.670
If I don't have this checked on, it's
gonna find a lower case Alice as well.

425
00:22:13.670 --> 00:22:15.492
So, figuring out which one you wanna do.
>> Keep those in mind, right, yeah.

426
00:22:15.492 --> 00:22:19.844
>> And sometimes what you have to do
is to do a search with the Find whole

427
00:22:19.844 --> 00:22:23.263
words only off, go through it,
and then all right,

428
00:22:23.263 --> 00:22:27.803
well now I need to do another search and
replace with that checked on.

429
00:22:27.803 --> 00:22:30.348
So sometimes you have to
do like multiple finds and

430
00:22:30.348 --> 00:22:33.330
replaces to make sure it gets
you exactly what you wanted.

431
00:22:33.330 --> 00:22:37.990
>> Still a whole lot easier than
rifling through each slide looking for

432
00:22:37.990 --> 00:22:38.700
the exact thing.

433
00:22:38.700 --> 00:22:40.170
And you'll miss a few, am I right?

434
00:22:40.170 --> 00:22:44.510
And then you go to present your slides and
people are like, Alice has been gone and,

435
00:22:44.510 --> 00:22:45.567
what have you done?

436
00:22:45.567 --> 00:22:47.694
You know, that's bad form.

437
00:22:47.694 --> 00:22:49.200
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, and that's,

438
00:22:49.200 --> 00:22:52.020
again, where the Replace and
the Replace all do it all for me.

439
00:22:52.020 --> 00:22:55.431
Sometimes you might wanna be careful about
that, cuz it will do things like, ooh,

440
00:22:55.431 --> 00:22:57.150
that was the wrong place for
us to do that.

441
00:22:57.150 --> 00:23:01.635
[LAUGH] So, I could go through and
find the next one, and this one I say,

442
00:23:01.635 --> 00:23:06.660
yep, replace that one,
let's go ahead and replace this one.

443
00:23:06.660 --> 00:23:13.770
And then, I think my dialogue box is
behind there, Replace here, Replace here.

444
00:23:13.770 --> 00:23:16.930
That's where right now,
since I didn't have the Match case like,

445
00:23:16.930 --> 00:23:20.620
this is like a different word
all together for some reason.

446
00:23:20.620 --> 00:23:21.719
I don't want to replace this,

447
00:23:21.719 --> 00:23:25.180
it's like no, let's go ahead and find the
next one and it won't replace that one.

448
00:23:25.180 --> 00:23:28.450
>> The last slide actually or
maybe even this one,

449
00:23:28.450 --> 00:23:31.160
was a great about the context, right?

450
00:23:31.160 --> 00:23:31.782
>> Mm-hm.

451
00:23:31.782 --> 00:23:32.749
>> The context was different,

452
00:23:32.749 --> 00:23:34.527
it was talking about Alice
sitting with her sister.

453
00:23:34.527 --> 00:23:36.677
If you change that Daniel
sitting with her sister,

454
00:23:36.677 --> 00:23:38.430
all of a sudden that doesn't make sense.

455
00:23:38.430 --> 00:23:40.790
So it's good that we were going
through it one at a time.

456
00:23:40.790 --> 00:23:44.758
Instead of going, yeah, just get rid
of Alice and replace it with Daniel and

457
00:23:44.758 --> 00:23:47.160
now Daniel's like, [SOUND]
>> [LAUGH]

458
00:23:47.160 --> 00:23:48.410
>> That's not making a lot

459
00:23:48.410 --> 00:23:49.335
of sense to me right here.

460
00:23:49.335 --> 00:23:50.899
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, and that's another reason,

461
00:23:50.899 --> 00:23:52.070
always go back and proof.

462
00:23:52.070 --> 00:23:52.666
>> Yes, proof.
>> Yes, read it.

463
00:23:52.666 --> 00:23:54.719
And then give it to
somebody else to proof.

464
00:23:54.719 --> 00:23:55.315
>> And then proof their proof.

465
00:23:55.315 --> 00:23:56.925
>> And then you proof again [LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

466
00:23:56.925 --> 00:23:59.148
[LAUGH]
>> There was one, read up side down.

467
00:23:59.148 --> 00:24:00.134
Or read it backwards.

468
00:24:00.134 --> 00:24:04.406
>> Yeah.
>> Instead of going linear, especially for

469
00:24:04.406 --> 00:24:06.707
checking punctuation.

470
00:24:06.707 --> 00:24:08.130
That's a big one to do.

471
00:24:08.130 --> 00:24:09.766
I would always proof
our books upside down.

472
00:24:09.766 --> 00:24:10.710
>> Okay.

473
00:24:10.710 --> 00:24:14.360
>> So find and replace can be
super handy to get the text.

474
00:24:14.360 --> 00:24:18.050
Cuz maybe you've gotten text into it,
you've pasted it from other places,

475
00:24:18.050 --> 00:24:22.550
you've done your paste options, and
then you've got things that I need to fix.

476
00:24:22.550 --> 00:24:24.470
Find and replace can be super helpful.

477
00:24:24.470 --> 00:24:27.430
And those paste options
especially if you're copying and

478
00:24:27.430 --> 00:24:28.770
pasting from the Internet.

479
00:24:28.770 --> 00:24:30.851
>> Yeah.
>> So if you went out to a website and

480
00:24:30.851 --> 00:24:35.512
you get everything, it can do some really
strange formatting in there because it's

481
00:24:35.512 --> 00:24:37.890
using HTML or hyper text markup language.

482
00:24:37.890 --> 00:24:41.153
So it might be pulling in pictures and
tables and what you think

483
00:24:41.153 --> 00:24:45.255
is just regular text it pastes in, you're
like I have no idea what I just did.

484
00:24:45.255 --> 00:24:45.815
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

485
00:24:45.815 --> 00:24:49.136
>> Or even when you go ahead and
say keep text only,

486
00:24:49.136 --> 00:24:53.970
you might be bringing in things that
you didn't even see on the page.

487
00:24:53.970 --> 00:24:56.278
It might be bringing in
alt text from an image or

488
00:24:56.278 --> 00:24:58.837
just things that you're
maybe not familiar with.

489
00:24:58.837 --> 00:25:01.819
But just kinda go through these
different paste options and

490
00:25:01.819 --> 00:25:05.250
get it close enough to where you
can get what you want out of it.

491
00:25:05.250 --> 00:25:09.730
And then a little trick though I've
found if you paste it into Notepad, or

492
00:25:09.730 --> 00:25:14.750
some very basic type of text program,

493
00:25:14.750 --> 00:25:18.665
that doesn't do the formatting
like Word or PowerPoint like that.

494
00:25:18.665 --> 00:25:21.365
It will automatically strip
everything out of it and

495
00:25:21.365 --> 00:25:26.825
then you can copy from that Notepad or
notes and then paste it into your product.

496
00:25:26.825 --> 00:25:28.020
>> So use that as a filter?

497
00:25:28.020 --> 00:25:28.865
>> Mm-hm, yeah.

498
00:25:28.865 --> 00:25:31.085
>> Let's get it the way you want
it before you try to drop in,

499
00:25:31.085 --> 00:25:32.952
then have to work with
it inside of PowerPoint.

500
00:25:32.952 --> 00:25:37.752
>> Yeah, especially coming up from PDFs
depending on how PDFs are created from

501
00:25:37.752 --> 00:25:39.638
whatever offering program.

502
00:25:39.638 --> 00:25:44.853
When you select it,
it does these weird, like enter marks.

503
00:25:44.853 --> 00:25:49.670
If you can just get it into like a
stripped out program that just does text,

504
00:25:49.670 --> 00:25:51.960
as in some very basic text editor.

505
00:25:51.960 --> 00:25:53.480
Then you can kind of
clean it up from there,

506
00:25:53.480 --> 00:25:58.630
trying to go into a program
such as Word or PowerPoint.

507
00:25:58.630 --> 00:26:01.230
It's almost like you're making
more work for yourself.

508
00:26:01.230 --> 00:26:04.370
So let the little guys do the work and

509
00:26:04.370 --> 00:26:06.990
then bring it into the big
guys to do some formatting.

510
00:26:06.990 --> 00:26:07.745
>> Excellent stuff.

511
00:26:07.745 --> 00:26:11.800
Vonne, you are a wealth of knowledge when
it comes to this PowerPoint business.

512
00:26:11.800 --> 00:26:13.615
I guess that's why we hired you.

513
00:26:13.615 --> 00:26:15.860
[LAUGH] Cuz you actually
know how to use this thing.

514
00:26:15.860 --> 00:26:19.800
So we do appreciate you sharing that
knowledge with us though and like I said I

515
00:26:19.800 --> 00:26:22.940
learned a lot of things today that
I had no idea were even a thing.

516
00:26:22.940 --> 00:26:26.330
And now we all do, we can jump in
there and edit work with text,

517
00:26:26.330 --> 00:26:27.000
do things with it.

518
00:26:27.000 --> 00:26:32.730
That's probably the majority of what we'll
be doing when we're modifying text, not

519
00:26:32.730 --> 00:26:35.570
that we won't play around with it, make
it a little purple, it's gonna be fun.

520
00:26:35.570 --> 00:26:39.020
But we gotta make it look right before
we start adding those types of features.

521
00:26:39.020 --> 00:26:41.210
So Vonne, you've done a great job,
thank you so much for today.

522
00:26:41.210 --> 00:26:43.370
>> Thank you.
>> We thank you for watching, but

523
00:26:43.370 --> 00:26:46.055
it looks like it's that time ladies and
gents for us to sign off.

524
00:26:46.055 --> 00:26:48.580
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

525
00:26:48.580 --> 00:26:49.204
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

526
00:26:49.204 --> 00:26:50.916
>> And we'll see you next time.

527
00:26:50.916 --> 00:26:56.687
[MUSIC]

528
00:26:56.687 --> 00:27:00.114
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne take a look at Character and Paragraph formatting in PowerPoint 2016. Here you will learn the the difference between Characters and Paragraphs, as well as the common attributes that can be manipulated. They also discuss some foundational typographical knowledge.
episodes.title: Character and Paragraph Formatting

WEBVTT

greetings everyone, and welcome to

And in today's episode,
we are coming back at you with, obviously,

00:00:21.679 --> 00:00:23.660

Well, at least hopefully
that's what you're here for.

If you're here for basket-weaving,

00:00:28.530 --> 00:00:30.550
Oddly enough, though,
our host could help you out with that,

00:00:30.550 --> 00:00:32.660

00:00:32.660 --> 00:00:34.683
And joining us in the studio is Ms.
Vonne Smith.

00:00:34.683 --> 00:00:36.530
Vonne, welcome back, how's it going?

15
00:00:36.530 --> 00:00:37.150
>> I'm great.

16
00:00:37.150 --> 00:00:38.650
>> I just assume you
know how to basket-weave.

17

>> I did take underwater

00:00:40.810 --> 00:00:43.480

So I'm not sure if I'd be much help.

[LAUGH]

00:00:53.420 --> 00:00:57.470
is all about fonts, and all about

24

And that's what we're going
to be doing in this episode.

25
00:00:59.498 --> 00:01:05.310
This episode is gonna be more about
explaining the concepts behind typography.

26
00:01:05.310 --> 00:01:09.770
And then, in the next episode,
we're going to be actually creating and

27
00:01:09.770 --> 00:01:11.330
applying the formats that
we're gonna talk about.

28
00:01:11.330 --> 00:01:14.830
But there's just so much that I wanna
talk about, in the world of typography.

29
00:01:14.830 --> 00:01:19.110
So I wanted to create our own episode,
to go through everything.

30
00:01:19.110 --> 00:01:24.316
>> Well, Ms. Vonne, please enlighten us,
you've got us, our appetites' whetted.

31
00:01:24.316 --> 00:01:26.076
Don't leave us hanging, where do we begin?

32
00:01:26.076 --> 00:01:28.716
>> Well, we're gonna begin with the first
slide in our PowerPoint presentation

33
00:01:28.716 --> 00:01:29.316
that I've made.

34
00:01:29.316 --> 00:01:31.852
About character and paragraph formatting.

35
00:01:31.852 --> 00:01:35.261
>> How apropos [LAUGH]
>> Yes, I know, so on this slide,

36
00:01:35.261 --> 00:01:37.477
it's just a basic overview.

37
00:01:37.477 --> 00:01:40.458
Because when you're talking
about formatting text,

38
00:01:40.458 --> 00:01:42.990
you're talking about
changing how it looks.

39
00:01:42.990 --> 00:01:46.014
Whether it be the font, the size,
the color, the alignment.

40
00:01:46.014 --> 00:01:49.192
All of those things that we
usually lump all together,

41
00:01:49.192 --> 00:01:51.930
as just making the text look differently.

42
00:01:51.930 --> 00:01:56.920
But when you're talking about formatting,
you do have two levels of formatting.

43
00:01:56.920 --> 00:02:00.610
You have character-level formatting, and

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore applying Character and Paragraph formatting of the text on a PowerPoint slide. They demonstrate formatting techniques like case, color, spacing, tracking, and symbols for Characters and alignment, line spacing, and indents for Paragraphs. Other topics covered includes Bullets and Numbering.

00:21:21.060 --> 00:21:26.300
you can see it's kind of adjusting, but it
is gonna head in creating lines spacing or

462
00:21:26.300 --> 00:21:30.510
space between all of my lines,
not just between the paragraphs.

463
00:21:30.510 --> 00:21:33.840
I'm going to take this back and
put it to one, so

464
00:21:33.840 --> 00:21:37.620
I want single space here and
I'm also going to,

465
00:21:37.620 --> 00:21:43.550
I'm going to create some other paragraphs
just for demonstration purposes even.

466
00:21:44.730 --> 00:21:45.500
You'll see what I'm saying.

467
00:21:45.500 --> 00:21:48.830
So, I'm gonna go ahead and select
this because I do wanna create space

468
00:21:48.830 --> 00:21:52.020
after paragraph, not between the lines.

469
00:21:52.020 --> 00:21:56.370
If I come over here to Line Spacing,
that is in the More options within this.

470
00:21:56.370 --> 00:22:01.840
So, Line Spacing Options, and here,
down here is where you Spacing.

471
00:22:01.840 --> 00:22:03.730
For some reason in PowerPoint and

472
00:22:03.730 --> 00:22:07.682
some of our other Office products it
likes to always put the space before.

473
00:22:07.682 --> 00:22:12.420
This is a personal preference, I don't
like putting space before paragraphs,

474
00:22:12.420 --> 00:22:14.560
I like to do space after
because if you think about it,

475
00:22:14.560 --> 00:22:18.190
you're travelling down if I'm
formatting I'm usually formatting down.

476
00:22:18.190 --> 00:22:21.120
So, I don't like to think
of anything in front of it.

477
00:22:21.120 --> 00:22:22.070
That's just me.

478
00:22:22.070 --> 00:22:23.870
It's totally up to you
how you want to do this.

479
00:22:23.870 --> 00:22:26.110
But I'm gonna take this before space.

480
00:22:26.110 --> 00:22:30.420
I'm gonna put it to zero and then,
on the, I always forget this [LAUGH].

481
00:22:30.420 --> 00:22:34.550
If you don't put in the PT
because they measure spacing and

482
00:22:34.550 --> 00:22:39.540
points here, it says that it's invalid, so
just hit the bump arrows, as I call them.

483
00:22:39.540 --> 00:22:44.144
Just hit the bumpy arrows down to where
it gets to 0 PT for points and then,

484
00:22:44.144 --> 00:22:46.720
if I want it after I can bump that up.

485
00:22:46.720 --> 00:22:50.350
And if you do want to physically type
in like 16 or something different,

486
00:22:50.350 --> 00:22:54.930
just make sure that you keep the PT or
the points after it.

487
00:22:54.930 --> 00:22:58.780
And then, you could also choose
the spacing from here if you wanted to.

488
00:22:58.780 --> 00:23:02.445
I'm gonna keep it a single from
what I had before, I click okay.

489
00:23:02.445 --> 00:23:08.115
And do you see how now the spacing is
coming after each change in paragraph,

490
00:23:08.115 --> 00:23:10.530
not in every line.

491
00:23:10.530 --> 00:23:12.870
Whichever way you want
it to look is up to you.

492
00:23:12.870 --> 00:23:16.520
And especially when we get into bullets,
when we start formatting our bullets,

493
00:23:16.520 --> 00:23:23.230
it's almost gonna be that line spacing and
paragraph spacing is the same.

494
00:23:23.230 --> 00:23:27.550
That's only if you have bullets that only
occupy a single line, that don't go and

495
00:23:27.550 --> 00:23:32.100
actually do the automatic break,and
go down into the next line.

496
00:23:32.100 --> 00:23:35.750
So, it really just depends on how
much stuff you've got in there.

497
00:23:37.810 --> 00:23:39.710
Let's see, where are we gonna go next?

498
00:23:39.710 --> 00:23:44.600
I wanted to, let's go ahead and
clear the formatting on all of this.

499
00:23:44.600 --> 00:23:48.680
And I just realized that it's only gonna
clear the character formatting, so.

500
00:23:48.680 --> 00:23:49.180
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

501
00:23:49.180 --> 00:23:50.340
>> Why don't we go ahead and

502
00:23:50.340 --> 00:23:53.602
take this back?
And we'll just take the space after Off,

503
00:23:53.602 --> 00:23:57.280
remember I said, you've gotta do
the bumpy errors, there we go.

504
00:23:57.280 --> 00:23:59.174
So, we'll do zero and

505
00:23:59.174 --> 00:24:01.567
now I have some space here and

506
00:24:01.567 --> 00:24:06.377
I wanted to put this into two columns.
So if I want to do columns, we can

507
00:24:06.377 --> 00:24:10.392
come over to this button right here.
And I can go ahead and say, do I want two,

508
00:24:10.392 --> 00:24:12.428
three columns?
Let's just go with two for

509
00:24:12.428 --> 00:24:14.980
now.
And so now you see that it broke apart

510
00:24:14.980 --> 00:24:18.775
this space, this content place
holder into two columns.

511
00:24:18.775 --> 00:24:20.731
But I like the columns, but

512
00:24:20.731 --> 00:24:24.684
I want more space between them.
That's where if you go into

513
00:24:24.684 --> 00:24:29.053
the More Columns dialog box or options,
this is where you can go ahead and

514
00:24:29.053 --> 00:24:32.127
do this spacing between columns.
And I can go ahead and

515
00:24:32.127 --> 00:24:35.323
bump that up to maybe, I'll just
go with half an inch or click OK.

516
00:24:35.323 --> 00:24:38.235
And see how now that space between

517
00:24:38.235 --> 00:24:42.089
the columns is going to
show up a lot better.

518
00:24:42.089 --> 00:24:44.332
The other thing we could do for

519
00:24:44.332 --> 00:24:47.940
our paragraphs while
forming is our indents.

520
00:24:47.940 --> 00:24:51.500
I'm actually gonna come back over
here to slide three, just cuz I

521
00:24:51.500 --> 00:24:56.490
don't have as much paragraph level
performance on this particular slide.

522
00:24:56.490 --> 00:24:57.540
So we'll stay with this.

523
00:24:58.740 --> 00:25:04.670
Indents, easiest way to do indents
is to control it with your ruler.

524
00:25:04.670 --> 00:25:09.780
If you do not see the ruler up here,
you can go to the view tab on the ribbon,

525
00:25:09.780 --> 00:25:13.790
and there is a check box for ruler.

526
00:25:13.790 --> 00:25:18.260
So if I check that on, or off, you can see
it's gone, check it back on, it's back on.

527
00:25:18.260 --> 00:25:22.840
So, it's important because of
these characters right here.

528
00:25:22.840 --> 00:25:25.780
There is a triangle pointing down,
there is a triangle pointing up,

529
00:25:25.780 --> 00:25:29.750
and there is a rectangle
underneath both of them.

530
00:25:29.750 --> 00:25:33.210
With my cursor in the paragraph
that I wanna format,

531
00:25:33.210 --> 00:25:38.360
if you pull the top triangle in,
that is your first line indent.

532
00:25:38.360 --> 00:25:42.770
How does the first line get treated as
opposed to where the rest of the text is

533
00:25:42.770 --> 00:25:44.036
going to be located?

534
00:25:44.036 --> 00:25:47.960
The rectangle underneath it,
that moves both.

535
00:25:47.960 --> 00:25:52.885
If you now have changed, it doesn't matter
if they're on top of each other or they're

536
00:25:52.885 --> 00:25:57.352
different if you move the rectangle you
are now moving the entire left indent.

537
00:25:57.352 --> 00:26:00.631
Depending on where and
how the first line is treated.

538
00:26:00.631 --> 00:26:06.923
So you can use those triangles on
the ribbon to indent your first line or

539
00:26:06.923 --> 00:26:12.696
do a hanging indent, go ahead and
move your entire left indent.

540
00:26:12.696 --> 00:26:15.719
And so just really I sort of say,
start pulling one way or the other,

541
00:26:15.719 --> 00:26:16.525
see what it does.

542
00:26:16.525 --> 00:26:17.380
>> Have a good time with it, right?

543
00:26:17.380 --> 00:26:20.400
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, but the top is the first line.

544
00:26:20.400 --> 00:26:25.340
The second triangle is the hanging indent,

545
00:26:25.340 --> 00:26:28.900
where in a second we'll see that's
where the text start and the bullet.

546
00:26:28.900 --> 00:26:33.320
And so that's where you could
format your indents on the ruler.

547
00:26:33.320 --> 00:26:38.020
Moving on to our Bullets and
Numbering, so here's our bullets.

548
00:26:38.020 --> 00:26:40.893
I don't like the little dot,
I want that to be different.

549
00:26:40.893 --> 00:26:43.582
Maybe it wants to be
like a little check box,

550
00:26:43.582 --> 00:26:46.501
maybe I want the check box to be orange,
right?

551
00:26:46.501 --> 00:26:50.220
We can have our orange and
black text going along with our Garfield.

552
00:26:50.220 --> 00:26:55.025
So I want to format all of these bullets
so I'm going to go ahead and select them.

553
00:26:56.105 --> 00:27:00.455
I'm then going to come over here to the
Home, and then here's the bullets button.

554
00:27:00.455 --> 00:27:03.465
This is number, so if I did wanna choose
them in the numbering instead of bullets,

555
00:27:03.465 --> 00:27:04.985
you can go ahead and click that.

556
00:27:04.985 --> 00:27:08.000
But each one of them
has different options.

557
00:27:08.000 --> 00:27:10.739
The drop down next to it will go ahead and

558
00:27:10.739 --> 00:27:14.312
allow you to choose
a different bullet character.

559
00:27:14.312 --> 00:27:15.400
Now it gives you a couple of them.

560
00:27:15.400 --> 00:27:18.834
But maybe I don't want any of these,
I want something different.

561
00:27:18.834 --> 00:27:22.090
In our previous show we saw some
with bunnies on there, right?

562
00:27:22.090 --> 00:27:25.040
So you can go into the Bullets and
Numbering.

563
00:27:25.040 --> 00:27:29.900
And then it has the options for
your different characters right here,

564
00:27:29.900 --> 00:27:30.970
within the little flower.

565
00:27:30.970 --> 00:27:32.360
And down at the bottom,

566
00:27:32.360 --> 00:27:36.180
that's where you could go all the way
through your different emoji characters.

567
00:27:36.180 --> 00:27:40.466
And then you can go into these different
symbols that you wanted to insert here.

568
00:27:40.466 --> 00:27:45.702
So we could go back to the,
something square, the knotted square?

569
00:27:45.702 --> 00:27:46.488
>> The looped square.

570
00:27:46.488 --> 00:27:48.884
>> The looped square, yes [LAUGH].

571
00:27:48.884 --> 00:27:52.410
So we could go ahead and
find the looped square, there is is.

572
00:27:52.410 --> 00:27:57.180
Maybe I want that to be my bullet
character, so I go ahead and find that.

573
00:27:57.180 --> 00:28:00.458
And I want the bullet character
to be a different color,

574
00:28:00.458 --> 00:28:03.893
well then you can come over here
to the color of the bullet.

575
00:28:03.893 --> 00:28:06.448
The size, sometimes the bullet characters,

576
00:28:06.448 --> 00:28:09.012
when you choose them
they're not big enough.

577
00:28:09.012 --> 00:28:12.725
So you can say like what percentage
of the font do you want it to be, and

578
00:28:12.725 --> 00:28:16.459
then if you really wanted to you
could actually choose a photograph.

579
00:28:16.459 --> 00:28:19.054
Now these bullets think about
a photograph as a picture or

580
00:28:19.054 --> 00:28:22.889
else the bullet's gonna be really really
small, so you don't want like some really

581
00:28:22.889 --> 00:28:26.250
ornate photograph as your bullet
it might get a little crazy.

582
00:28:26.250 --> 00:28:29.151
So I'm gonna choose that,
gonna click okay but

583
00:28:29.151 --> 00:28:33.731
you see now how the text is really,
really close to that bullet character.

584
00:28:33.731 --> 00:28:36.570
So I want it to kind of
move off a little bit.

585
00:28:36.570 --> 00:28:37.482
>> Give it some breathing room.

586
00:28:37.482 --> 00:28:40.240
>> Yes,
we need some breathing room right there.

587
00:28:40.240 --> 00:28:43.448
So that's where you want to take
the bottom triangle, not the top,

588
00:28:43.448 --> 00:28:45.147
cuz that's where the bullet sits.

589
00:28:45.147 --> 00:28:49.214
So in this sense, the top triangle
is where the bullet is, the bottom

590
00:28:49.214 --> 00:28:53.931
triangle is where the text is going to be
related to that and so you see if I start.

591
00:28:53.931 --> 00:28:56.352
Whoops, I grabbed the wrong one there,
this one.

592
00:28:56.352 --> 00:28:56.919
>> Easy to do apparently.

593
00:28:56.919 --> 00:28:57.656
[LAUGH]
>> It is.

594
00:28:57.656 --> 00:28:58.944
It's very, very close together.

595
00:28:58.944 --> 00:29:01.577
So make sure on the triangle pointing up.

596
00:29:01.577 --> 00:29:04.507
And that way you see I can go ahead and

597
00:29:04.507 --> 00:29:08.917
separate the space between the text and
the bullets.

598
00:29:08.917 --> 00:29:11.930
And then we can go ahead and
do something like that.

599
00:29:11.930 --> 00:29:15.151
Now, I have this here.

600
00:29:15.151 --> 00:29:18.187
And a lot of times, when we start getting
into bullet formatting in Powerpoint,

601
00:29:18.187 --> 00:29:20.703
everyone's like, well,
is this going to go for all of my slides?

602
00:29:20.703 --> 00:29:23.873
Cuz I have 65 slides
that have bullets on it.

603
00:29:23.873 --> 00:29:24.448
No.

604
00:29:24.448 --> 00:29:26.581
>> [LAUGH]
>> Not at this level, but

605
00:29:26.581 --> 00:29:29.544
you could do that in the slide master.

606
00:29:29.544 --> 00:29:32.182
The slide master is the place
where everything kind of gets its

607
00:29:32.182 --> 00:29:33.000
formatting from.

608
00:29:33.000 --> 00:29:35.230
You still need to know
how to format bullets.

609
00:29:35.230 --> 00:29:37.200
Because you need to know where it's at.

610
00:29:37.200 --> 00:29:41.110
But if you format it on the slide master,
then all the slides that have bullets will

611
00:29:41.110 --> 00:29:46.170
go ahead and obey that master and
be able to use that formatting.

612
00:29:46.170 --> 00:29:50.894
But for now, I really wanna take this and
copy this formatting to somewhere else.

613
00:29:50.894 --> 00:29:56.524
And that's where the format
painter can come in handy.

614
00:29:56.524 --> 00:30:01.004
So we can take our text now, the thing
is you do need to make sure you select

615
00:30:01.004 --> 00:30:03.809
the entire paragraph, meaning all of this.

616
00:30:03.809 --> 00:30:08.165
Because the bullet character is part of
that paragraph and the format is like,

617
00:30:08.165 --> 00:30:11.269
its kind of like painting
a house you have a can of paint.

618
00:30:11.269 --> 00:30:14.163
You take the paint brush, you put it in
a can of paint and then you take it and

619
00:30:14.163 --> 00:30:15.310
paint on the house.

620
00:30:15.310 --> 00:30:20.723
So we're basically saying here we select
this text that this is the can of paint.

621
00:30:20.723 --> 00:30:24.651
I'm gonna get my paintbrush,
which is right here on the Home tab.

622
00:30:24.651 --> 00:30:26.369
I'm going to click it and so

623
00:30:26.369 --> 00:30:31.536
now it's saying that I've got the paint
on the paintbrush from that can of paint.

624
00:30:31.536 --> 00:30:36.336
And if I click hold and drag over here,
do you see how that will go ahead and

625
00:30:36.336 --> 00:30:38.482
copy the formatting from that.

626
00:30:38.482 --> 00:30:43.731
Not the text, it's just the formats of it,
and then it goes ahead and applies.

627
00:30:43.731 --> 00:30:44.955
And notice it's gone.

628
00:30:44.955 --> 00:30:47.060
It's like a one-time thing.

629
00:30:47.060 --> 00:30:51.811
If you wanted it to stay on, like
the whole time, I'm gonna come back here,

630
00:30:51.811 --> 00:30:55.008
if you double-click
the format painter there is,

631
00:30:55.008 --> 00:30:57.785
where it kind of keeps
the gun on as I call it.

632
00:30:57.785 --> 00:31:00.248
It's kind of like the spray gun
that you can spray houses with.

633
00:31:00.248 --> 00:31:05.150
If you double click it, then I can go
ahead and select here, I can select here.

634
00:31:05.150 --> 00:31:08.280
And then sometimes and
it's like I could select here and okay,

635
00:31:08.280 --> 00:31:09.480
now I'm getting a little too crazy.

636
00:31:09.480 --> 00:31:11.360
It's like it's scrolling everywhere.

637
00:31:11.360 --> 00:31:15.470
It's like if you turn the gun on,
you can turn the gun off.

638
00:31:15.470 --> 00:31:19.350
So you have to come back up
here to the paintbrush and

639
00:31:19.350 --> 00:31:23.060
turn it off to say all right,
I'm done copying.

640
00:31:23.060 --> 00:31:27.415
Now, I have a few other things that I want
to show, cuz I said all about the tabs,

641
00:31:27.415 --> 00:31:29.400
how much I love to format tabs.

642
00:31:29.400 --> 00:31:31.655
But I can see you're kind
of giving me the, hey,

643
00:31:31.655 --> 00:31:33.311
we're starting to run out of time.

644
00:31:33.311 --> 00:31:37.223
So, I think we might go ahead and
just make a small part two out of this and

645
00:31:37.223 --> 00:31:40.825
come back to show you about all
the wonderful world the tab stops.

646
00:31:40.825 --> 00:31:42.967
And then also how we're going
to formating our speaker nets.

647
00:31:42.967 --> 00:31:43.835
>> That sounds fantastic.

648
00:31:43.835 --> 00:31:45.186
It's a great idea.

649
00:31:45.186 --> 00:31:47.909
We don't want to overwhelm
you good people.

650
00:31:47.909 --> 00:31:49.288
We don't want you drinking
from a fire hose, right?

651
00:31:49.288 --> 00:31:52.188
So we'll just break this
into a small part two, and

652
00:31:52.188 --> 00:31:54.422
we'll finish that up in that episode.

653
00:31:54.422 --> 00:31:56.071
So definitely join us in for that.

654
00:31:56.071 --> 00:31:58.494
Vonne, thanks for
getting to where we are at so far.

655
00:31:58.494 --> 00:32:00.240
Can't wait to see where you're
gonna take us in the next show.

656
00:32:00.240 --> 00:32:01.831
So we'll be there for that one.

657
00:32:01.831 --> 00:32:05.398
As far as this episode goes,
we need to shut it down.

658
00:32:05.398 --> 00:32:07.938
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

659
00:32:07.938 --> 00:32:08.690
>> I'm Vonne Smith.

660
00:32:08.690 --> 00:32:10.700
>> And we'll see you next time.

661
00:32:10.700 --> 00:32:16.631
[MUSIC]

662
00:32:16.631 --> 00:32:20.182
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne finish exploring applying Character and Paragraph formatting of the text on a PowerPoint slide. Here they show you how to effectively work with Tab spacing as well as formatting text in the Speaker Notes section.
episodes.title: Format Text Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne demonstrate employing images in a PowerPoint presentation. They kick things off by looking at how to insert an image into a slide. Then they look at sizing images, file type importance, and the Picture Format tab.
episodes.title: Images

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore Format Slides and Themes. This episode is al about changing the look and feel of the entire presentation and the slides therein. They will look at default design themes and even make custom themes. Other topics covered include formatting the background and design ideas.
episodes.title: Format Slides and Themes

episodes.description: In this episode, Zac and Vonne show us how to add and format shapes in PowerPoint. Vonne also covers stacking order, the selection pane, aligning, and grouping.
episodes.title: Shapes

episodes.description: Zac and Vonne continue working with shapes in PowerPoint, covering topics such as merging shapes, editing points, shapes with modifying handles, and adding text to shapes.
episodes.title: Shapes Part 2

episodes.description: Zac and Vonne take a look at using SmartArt in PowerPoint. SmartArt is a combination of shapes and text that help to convey data in a graphical format. They demonstrate how easy it is use and add them to our presentation. Vonne shows us how to add shapes to SmartArt, delete and modify shapes, apply styles, and use the list view in a variety of different types of SmartArt available in the SmartArt library.
episodes.title: SmartArt

episodes.description: In this episode, Zac and Vonne discuss tables in PowerPoint. Vonne demonstrates the different parts of a created table and show how they can be manipulated and formatted. She then shows how to create a table and add data as well as formatting to make the table display the way we want for a presentation.
episodes.title: Tables

episodes.description: In this episode, Zac and Vonne discuss the purpose and creation of charts in Microsoft PowerPoint. Charts allow us to summarize and compare data in graphical representation. Vonne reviews the terminology associated with charts, chart types, how to insert a chart, add data to a chart, add and modify chart elements, as well as format charts for a presentation.
episodes.title: Charts

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Zac discuss how to add animations to a PowerPoint presentation. They demonstrate adding basic animations, modifying animations and adding multiple animations. They also look at using motion paths and custom paths with animations. They finish up by demonstrating adding sounds to animations and using animations with SmartArt.
episodes.title: Animation

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Zac demonstrate working with slide transitions in PowerPoint. They add slide transitions to a single slide and to all slides. They look at the different effect options available for some slide transitions. They also show how to add sounds and modify the duration of slide transitions.
episodes.title: Slide Transitions

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Mike look at the final stages of creating a PowerPoint presentation. They go over using spell check and the thesaurus. They discuss printing options, hiding slides, adding headers and footers, and running your presentation.
episodes.title: Prepare a Presentation

episodes.description: Vonne and Mike continue to look at the final stages of creating a PowerPoint presentation. They explore the different options available for sharing, exporting, and saving a PowerPoint presentation in different formats.
episodes.title: Prepare a Presentation Part 2
